entry.title: Obama: Kenya at 'crossroads' between peril and promise
entry.summary: "Because of Kenya's progress - because of your potential - you can build your future right here, right now," Obama told the crowd of 4,500 packed into a sports arena in the capital of Nairobi.

entry.title: Obama pushes Kenya to root out corruption
entry.summary: "Here in Kenya, it's time to change habits."

entry.title: Obama, in Africa, says Kenya at 'crossroads' between peril and promise
entry.summary: The president left Kenya Sunday afternoon, pausing longer than normal atop the stairs to Air Force One to wave to the crowd, a huge grin on his face.

entry.title: Obama: Kenya at 'crossroads' between peril and promise
Obama: Kenya at 'crossroads' between peril and promise
entry.summary: On the final day of his visit in Kenya, Obama laid out his vision for Kenya's future, and broad themes of U.S.-Kenya relations.

entry.title: Obama urges Kenya to use tough past to guide its future
entry.summary: President Barack Obama delivers a speech at the Safaricom Indoor Arena in the Kasarani area of Nairobi, Kenya Sunday, July 26, 2015.

entry.title: Obama says Kenya is at a crossroads; urges nation to ditch 'bad traditions'
entry.summary: After the speech, Mr Obama met with members of Kenya's vibrant civil society.

entry.title: Obama urges Kenya to use past to guide future
President Barack Obama to end historic Kenya visit with national address
entry.summary:
The president's late father was born and is buried in Kenya, and its people have waited for years for the chance to welcome Mr Obama back as president.

He made history by becoming the first sitting American president to visit Kenya when he arrived late on Friday.

entry.title: Obama calls for gay rights in Africa, challenges Kenya on corruption
entry.summary:
Kenya, like many African states, outlaws homosexual relations.

Kenyan deputy president William Ruto, who attended talks with Mr Obama, said in May there was "no room" for gays in Kenya.

entry.title: In Kenya, Obama blends blunt messages with warm reflections
entry.summary: President Barack Obama mixed blunt messages to Kenya's leaders on gay rights, corruption and counterterrorism Saturday with warm reflections on his family ties to a nation that considers him a local son.

entry.title: In Kenya, Obama blends blunt messages with warm reflections
entry.summary: Obama did little to paper over policy differences with Kenya's government, most notably on gay rights.

entry.title: In Kenya, Obama blends blunt messages with warm reflections
entry.summary: A number of Kenyan politicians and religious leaders had warned Obama that any overtures on gay rights would not be welcomed in Kenya, where gay sex is punishable by up to 14 years in prison.

entry.title: Obama thrills Kenyans, but also presses government on gay rights
entry.summary: "Kenya is leading the way."

entry.title: The Latest: Obama warns corruption may thwart Kenya's growth
entry.summary:
President Barack Obama is warning that corruption may be the biggest impediment to Kenya's growth and opportunities in the future.

Obama was asked about gay rights in Kenya at a joint news conference with Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta.

entry.title: Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary: U.S. President Barack Obama, left, stands next to Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta, 2nd left, as the Kenya Air Force military band passes by, at State House in Nairobi, Kenya Saturday, July 25, 2015.

entry.title: Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary: President Barack Obama, right, shakes hands with Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta before a bilateral meeting at State House, Saturday, July 25, 2015, in Nairobi, Kenya.

entry.title: White House Notebook: Kenya says it's no terror hotbed
entry.summary: Obama's visit to Kenya is focused on trade and economic issues, as well as security and counterterrorism cooperation.

entry.title: White House Notebook: Obama faces 'family politics' in Kenya
entry.summary: President Uhuru Kenyatta even joined in, telling attendees at the Global Entrepreneurship Summit that they will find Kenya to be "a hotbed of vibrant culture, spectacular natural beauty, and a wonderful people with infinite possibility."

entry.title: Obama returns to Kenya, reunites with father's family
entry.summary: President Barack Obama hugs his half-sister, Auma Obama, accompanied by Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta, right, as he arrives in Nairobi.

entry.title: Obama at Kenya business summit: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary:
U.S. President Barack Obama heralded Africa as a continent "on the move" Saturday as he opened a U.S.-sponsored business summit in Kenya, the East African nation where he has family ties.

He said he hoped Obama's visit would help change the narrative about Kenya and Africa.

entry.title: Barack Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary: Obama's visit to Kenya - the first by a sitting US president - has been highly anticipated in a nation that views him as a local son.

entry.title: Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary: The Kenya attack killed more than 200 Kenyans and 12 Americans at the embassy.

entry.title: Kenya welcomes President Obama
Kenya bids 'welcome home' to President Obama
entry.summary: President Barack Obama poses for a photograph with Joan Wamaitha, 8, who gave him flowers on his arrival at the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi, Kenya.

entry.title: Obama returns to Kenya, reunites with father's family
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) " Fulfilling the hopes of millions of Kenyans, Barack Obama returned to his father's homeland Friday for the first time as U.S. president, a long sought visit by a country that considers him a local son.

entry.title: Obama returns to Kenya, reunites with father's family
entry.summary: Auma Obama said she believed her late father would be proud to see his son return to Kenya as American president.

entry.title: Obama's link to Kenya: A father he barely knew
entry.summary: U.S. President Barack Obama waves after being greeted by Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta, right, on his arrival at the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi, Kenya Friday, July 24, 2015.

entry.title: Obama's link to Kenya: A father he barely knew
entry.summary:
Workers finish installing a large billboard showing Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta, left, and President Barack Obama, right, in downtown Nairobi, Kenya Thursday, July 23, 2015.

NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Barack Obama's link to Kenya, where he began his first visit as U.S. president Friday, is a father he barely knew but whose influence can nonetheless be seen in his son's presidency.

"In my father's life, it was partly tribalism and patronage and nepotism in an independent Kenya that for a long stretch derailed his career," Obama said during a 2009 trip to Ghana, his first visit to Africa as president.

The president's father, Barack Obama Sr., left Kenya as a young man to study at the University of Hawaii.

Obama's first trip to Kenya nearly 30 years ago was a quest to fill in the gaps in the story of his father's life.

entry.title: Barack Obama lands in Kenya as security patrols for al-Shabab militants
entry.summary:
Meanwhile, a massive security operation is in place to protect Obama during his visit to Kenya, which has been frequently targeted by al-Shabab militants based in neighbouring Somalia.

Al-Shabab, which is linked to al-Qaeda, has conducted major attacks in Kenya, including the 2013 attack on Nairobi's Westgate mall and an April attack in Garissa that killed nearly 150 people.

entry.title: Kenya bids ?welcome home? to President Obama
entry.summary: President Barack Obama arrives Friday in Kenya, the ancestral homeland that has waited impatiently for a visit from the U.S. president since he was first elected to office.

entry.title: Obama's visit to Kenya, Ethiopia sparks concerns over human rights and governance issues
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON - President Barack Obama's trip to Kenya and Ethiopia is drawing fresh criticism that the two countries are heavy-handed on human rights and basic democratic freedoms.

Obama will become the first sitting U.S. president to visit Kenya, his ancestral homeland, when he arrives Friday to attend a business summit and meetings with President Uhuru Kenyatta.

The letter to Obama said he should put the "pressing human rights concerns" in Kenya and Ethiopia "at the forefront of your discussions."

The letter expressed concern that both countries are using national security concerns to stifle the media as well as civic participation and, in Kenya, to crack down on Somali refugees who have fled the instability in their home country.

Kenya's deputy president, William Ruto, is also under indictment by the International Criminal Court for alleged links to violence after the 2007 election.

entry.title: As he heads to Africa, Obama's electricity plan in jeopardy
entry.summary: Although this week's trip to Kenya and Ethiopia will be Obama's third to sub-Saharan Africa as president, his global agenda has been largely focused on Asia and the Middle East.

entry.title: White House dismisses Kenya release of Obama schedule
entry.summary: The White House had announced earlier this year that Obama would travel to Kenya to attend a Global Entrepreneurship Summit.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary:
FILE - In this Saturday, Aug. 26, 2006 file photo, then U.S. Senator Barack Obama meets with his step-grandmother Sarah Obama at his father's house in Kogelo, western Kenya.

On Friday, July 24, 2015 Obama is due to arrive in Kenya, the country of his father's birth, for the first time since he was a U.S. senator in 2006, and the first stop on his two-nation African tour in which he will also visit Ethiopia.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary:
This week, Obama will make his first visit to Kenya as U.S. president, a trip that will bear little resemblance to the 1988 one, when he arrived aboard commercial flight and his luggage got lost.

Obama's re-election raised renewed hopes for a visit to Kenya, but the political situation there complicated those plans.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary: Even as a U.S. senator, he was greeted by cheering crowds when he made his last visit to Kenya, in 2006.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary: President Barack Obama is due to make his first trip as president to Kenya later in the month, the country of his father's birth, to attend the Global Entrepreneurship Summit, which brings together business leaders, international organizations and governments.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary: A chef walks past a cardboard cutout of President Barack Obama in the entrance way of the Cafe Deli coffee shop in downtown Nairobi, Kenya, Wednesday, July 22, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya prepares to welcome Obama to the country where his father was born
entry.summary: For many Kenyans, the Swahili-language slogan will be more than just a polite greeting when the American president visits the country where his father was born, his first trip to Kenya since he was a U.S. senator in 2006.

entry.title: Kenya prepares to welcome President Obama to the country where his father was born
entry.summary: Obama is scheduled to arrive in Kenya on Friday, the first stop on his two-nation African tour in which he will also visit Ethiopia.

entry.title: Kenya president says talks with Obama to focus on extremism
entry.summary: Kenya has been working closely with American security agencies in the fight against extremism and the meeting with Obama will further strengthen this cooperation, Kenyatta said.

entry.title: Kenya president says talks with Obama to focus on extremism
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) " Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta says the fight against extremism will be the key topic of talks with U.S. President Barack Obama, who will be visiting the country of his father later this week.

Kenya is battling a wave of extremist attacks by al-Qaida-linked al-Shabab militants from Somalia that has killed more than 400 people since October 2011 when the country sent troops into Somalia to fight the militants.

entry.title: Shoppers return to Kenya's Westgate mall nearly two years after terrorist attack
entry.summary: The event came less than a week before US President Barack Obama's planned visit to Kenya, when he will underscore American support for the war against al-Shabab.

entry.title: Shoppers return to Kenyan mall 2 years after attack
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) " Hundreds of shoppers thronged through the reopened Westgate Shopping Mall in Kenya's capital, Nairobi nearly two years after a terrorist attack there left at least 67 people dead.

entry.title: Kenya mall reopens after 2013 terror attack
Kenya's Westgate shopping mall reopens
Al-Shabaab jihadists linked to Kenya attacks 'killed by drone'
entry.summary: In April, four Shebab militants massacred 148 people at the Garissa University in Kenya's northeast, in what was the group's deadliest single attack to date.

entry.title: Kenya press freedom rapidly deteriorating, rights group says
entry.summary:
The deteriorating climate for the media comes at a time when press scrutiny and public discussion are essential for continued development of Kenya's democracy and economy, the report said.

Also needing press scrutiny, according to the report, is the situation for Kenya's deputy president who is under indictment from the International Criminal Court, although similar charges were dropped against the president.

entry.title: Kenya press freedom rapidly deteriorating, rights group says
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) " Press freedom is deteriorating in Kenya as a result of government legislation, threats and attacks, a media rights group said Wednesday.

entry.title: Nairobi mall to re-open 2 years after extremist attack
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya - Nairobi's Westgate Mall is to re-open Saturday, nearly two years after it was attacked by Somalia' Islamic extremist rebels who killed at least 67 people, Kenyan officials said Tuesday.

But Kenya has rebounded from the violence, said Nairobi Governor Evans Kidero, who toured the mall on Tuesday.

Nairobi is safe and U.S .President Barack Obama's visit to the country later this month is testimony to Kenya's security, said Kidero who urged shoppers to turn out Saturday for the re-opening.

entry.title: Kenya Westgate Mall to re-open two years after al-Shabab attack
Islamic militants kill 14 in Kenya cross-border attack
entry.summary: On April 2 four al-Shabab gunmen carried out the group's deadliest attack yet on a university in eastern Kenya in which 148 people were killed, the majority of them students.

entry.title: Kenya says Islamic extremists kill 14 in Kenya's north
entry.summary: Kenya Police officers carry a body in Mandera, Kenya, Tuesday, July 7, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya says Islamic extremists kill 14 in Kenya's north
entry.summary: Eleven people were also wounded in the attack which took place in Soko Mbuzi village in Mandera County near Kenya's border with Somalia, said Mandera County Commissioner Alex Nkoyo.

entry.title: At least 14 dead in Kenya attack
Islamic extremists kill 14 in Kenya's north, official says
entry.summary: Al-Shabab has vowed to carry out attacks in Kenya as retribution for the country sending troops to Somalia to fight the militants.

entry.title: Kenya says Islamic extremists kill 14 in Kenya's north
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya - A Kenyan official says at least 14 people have been killed in an attack by al-Qaida-linked al-Shabab militants in the country's north.

Kenya sent its troops to Somalia in Oct 2011 following a series of cross-border attacks including kidnappings which the government blamed on al-Shabab.
